title: Poultry farm sales 'validate' asset values
text:
Over the past three months, the rural property trust has been under heavy fire from Texas-based activist short seller Bonitas Research and more recently from Hong Kong-based investment advisory firm, Bucephalus Research Partnership.

Both claim RFF overstated the value of its near $1 billion portfolio of assets and its profits – allegations rejected outright by RFM which is now suing Bonitas in the NSW Supreme Court.

Mr Bryant said ProTen, one of the country's biggest chicken farmers, would "do very well" out of the broiler sheds, which RFM believes are better suited to an owner with economies of scale.

RFF's biggest investments are in almond orchards and beef cattle properties. These two sectors will account for 75 per cent of its revenue this financial year.

The proceeds of the poultry sale (which requires approval by the unitholders of its lessee, National Stock Exchange-listed RFM Poultry) will be used to pay down debt and fund investments in "natural resource predominant assets" which RFM said had the potential for higher total returns.

Rural Funds will forego $11m in rent from the sale of the poultry sheds.

The first of these investments will be three WA cattle properties – Petro, High Hill and Willara north of Perth – which RFF has agreed to acquire from prominent pastoralist and businessman Brent Smoothy for $22.6 million. They will be leased to Wagyu beef producer Stone Axe Pastoral Company on 10-year terms. The acquisitions are expected to settle in April next year.

In light of these deals, which will remove about $11 million in annual poultry revenue, RFF cut its adjusted funds from operations (AFFO) expectations in fiscal 2020 to 13.4¢ per unit from the 14¢ per unit forecast given at its full-year results announcement in August.

The forecast full-year distribution for fiscal 2020 was unchanged at 10.85¢ per unit, but the payout ratio has increased to 81 per cent from 77 per cent.

RFM acknowledged the transactions would "marginally reduce AFFO in the short term" but said they would "deliver higher AFFO growth in the medium and long term"

Investors appeared to support this view, with RFF units rising 2.5 per cent to $1.83 by late afternoon on Monday.

RFF units were worth $2.35 prior to distribution of the first Bonitas report, which labelled RFF's equity "ultimately worthless".
description: Rural Funds Management managing director David Bryant says the sale of the poultry assets shows the agribusiness property trust has valued its assets correctly.
